verses.text: Can you draw out Leviathan with a fishhook, or tie down his tongue with a rope?
verses.comment: Leviathan represents a mighty, untamable monster. The rhetorical question emphasizes human limitation before divine creation.

verses.text: Can you put a cord through his nose, or pierce his jaw with a hook?
verses.comment: Questions reinforce the impossibility for man to control Leviathan, highlighting God’s sovereignty over all creation.

verses.text: Will he make many supplications to you? Will he speak soft words to you?
verses.comment: Leviathan is pictured as proud and unyielding, not subject to human authority or persuasion.

verses.text: Will he make a covenant with you, to take him as a servant forever?
verses.comment: The imagery points to the impossibility of domesticating this creature, echoing human inability to subdue chaos apart from God.

verses.text: Will you play with him as with a bird, or will you tie him up for your girls?
verses.comment: The notion of children playing with Leviathan intensifies the absurdity, highlighting God's power alone to master creation.

verses.text: Will traders bargain over him? Will they divide him among the merchants?
verses.comment: Leviathan’s value cannot be measured by commerce; his uniqueness reflects the mystery of God's works.

verses.text: Can you fill his skin with harpoons, or his head with fishing spears?
verses.comment: No human weapon can subdue Leviathan, illustrating God's control over even the strongest forces.

verses.text: Lay your hands on him; remember the battle—you will do it no more!
verses.comment: A warning about impossible endeavors without divine assistance, a reminder that spiritual warfare must rely on God's grace. (See Eph. 6:12)

verses.text: Hope of capturing him is false; just the sight of him will bring terror.
verses.comment: Leviathan evokes fear, paralleling humanity’s awe before divine mystery. This fosters humble trust in God's providence.

verses.text: No one is so fierce that he dares to stir him up. Who then is able to stand before me?
verses.comment: God’s ultimate authority is asserted; man’s terror before nature is nothing compared to the reverence before the Creator.

verses.text: Who has given to me, that I should repay him? Whatever is under all heaven belongs to me.
verses.comment: The assertion of ownership affirms God as Creator and sustainer of all things—a foundation for understanding divine providence.

verses.text: I will not keep silence about his limbs, or his mighty strength, or his graceful form.
verses.comment: God’s speech emphasizes the wonder of Leviathan, inviting contemplation of the beauty and complexity of creation.

verses.text: Who can strip off his outer coat? Who can come near him with a bridle?
verses.comment: Leviathan’s defensive armor further demonstrates human weakness before divine design.

verses.text: Who can open the doors of his face? His teeth are terrifying all around.
verses.comment: Description shifts from external protection to fearsome internal features, intensifying awe of God's works.

verses.text: His back is made of rows of shields, shut up tightly as with a seal.
verses.comment: The impenetrable armor symbolizes unstoppable force; a metaphor for evil or chaos which only God can restrain.

verses.text: One is so close to another that no air can come between them.
verses.comment: This detail magnifies Leviathan’s resistance to attack; the closeness recalls unity and strength.

verses.text: They are joined to each other; they clasp together and cannot be separated.
verses.comment: Unity of Leviathan’s armor is a reminder of the importance of spiritual unity among God's people. (See John 17:22)

verses.text: His sneezes flash forth light, and his eyes are like the eyelids of dawn.
verses.comment: Vivid supernatural images point to mysterious power, sometimes seen as symbols of underlying spiritual realities.

verses.text: Out of his mouth go flaming torches; sparks of fire leap forth.
verses.comment: Leviathan’s fire-breathing evokes later biblical imagery of spiritual warfare and the adversary’s power.

verses.text: Out of his nostrils comes smoke, as from a boiling pot and burning rushes.
verses.comment: Leviathan’s fiery breath relates to mythic expressions of chaos and evil, under God’s ultimate restraint.

verses.text: His breath kindles coals, and a flame comes out of his mouth.
verses.comment: Fire imagery is often tied to judgment and refinement, hinting at spiritual purification through divine trials.

verses.text: In his neck resides strength, and terror dances before him.
verses.comment: The neck as seat of power signifies steadfastness; spiritual terror is confronted not alone but through God’s grace.

verses.text: The folds of his flesh cling together; firm on him, they are not moved.
verses.comment: Emphasizes the creature's impenetrability and God’s creative mastery.

verses.text: His heart is as hard as a stone, as hard as a lower millstone.
verses.comment: A hard heart is occasionally a spiritual metaphor for resistance to repentance, yet even the hardest heart can be transformed by grace.

verses.text: When he rises up, the mighty are afraid; at his crashing they are beside themselves.
verses.comment: Human strength falters before Leviathan; only faith rooted in God brings peace.

verses.text: When the sword reaches him, it cannot avail; nor the spear, the dart, or the javelin.
verses.comment: Physical weapons are useless; spiritual victory requires reliance on God’s power, foreshadowing later biblical imagery. (See Eph. 6:13–17)

verses.text: He counts iron as straw and bronze as rotten wood.
verses.comment: Earthly might and materials are nothing before Leviathan, much more before God.

verses.text: The arrow cannot make him flee; slingstones are turned to stubble against him.
verses.comment: Reinforces the indomitable strength of Leviathan, drawing attention to God’s incomprehensible power.

verses.text: Clubs are counted as stubble; he laughs at the shaking of the javelin.
verses.comment: Leviathan’s contempt for weapons shows the futility of resisting forces beyond earthly means.

verses.text: His underparts are sharp as potsherds; he spreads himself like a threshing sledge on the mire.
verses.comment: Sharp underparts add to Leviathan’s dangerousness, symbolizing how evil and chaos lurk beneath what appears powerful.

verses.text: He makes the deep boil like a pot; he makes the sea like ointment.
verses.comment: Leviathan’s power over the sea evokes creation and the subduing of chaos, a theme fulfilled by Christ calming the storm.

verses.text: Behind him he leaves a shining wake; one would think the deep had white hair.
verses.comment: The poetic imagery enhances Leviathan's grandeur, reminding us of the mystery beyond human comprehension.

verses.text: On earth there is none like him, made without fear.
verses.comment: Uniqueness of Leviathan reflects the singular majesty and mystery of God’s creation. Leviathan is described as fearless, hinting at the final defeat of evil in salvation history.

verses.text: He looks down on all that are high; he is king over all the proud.
verses.comment: Echoes the biblical portrayal of pride and evil under God’s dominion. Leviathan ultimately is subject to God, foreshadowing Christ’s victory over darkness. Spiritually, tradition recognizes Leviathan as a symbol of spiritual evil, but the true King is the One who triumphs over all powers (see Col 2:15).
